children.subject:
In the past, it was

Mathematics 54, Physics 7A-7B, and either Physics 7C, Mathematics 55, or Computer Science 170

No clue if that still remains true, but it seems likely from the description.
There are no --have never been -- official prerequisites to the course.   That doesn't mean individual instructors haven't shared a list like this in various offerings of the course. Interesting.
What are the hard/soft prerequisites for this class?
Probably not...perhaps the next year.
Are there other courses at Cal to learn quantum computing?
(for example, is CS294-2 quantum computation planning to be offered next year?)

Courses to be offered for next academic year have not yet been committed to.  As soon as we are able to,  the tentative (draft) schedule for F17/SP18 will be listed here :  https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/CS/schedule-draft.html?_ga=1.62538732.1945271187.1416977033 

This is likely to occur in or by early January.
Will this be offered in either Fall 2017 or Spring 2018 semesters?
It hasnt been put onto schedule, so we dont have a cn yet (i think)
What's the CN?
Let's do it.
+1 Based God

I have a time conflict as well. I am curious if this will be webcasted or not, and if alternate final times would be offered...

I'm graduating too so its my last chance to take it :(
The class is set up to have a final exam.  We don't normally webcast courses whose enrollment is as relatively small as this one. Sorry.
Is there a final exam? I really want to take this class, but I have a time conflict.
You can't do anything until your phase II
Can we sign up for it as soon as it is opened? Or do we have to wait for our phase 2?

Either Monday or the following Monday.

Apologies for delay, cross-listing with three departments, new CalCentral...ugh!

Thank you! 
Apologies for the delay not needed, merely was hoping for specific days to check so I didn't have to check throughout thanksgiving. Thank you so much!
Any idea when this class will be in schedule for those of us who already are able to do their phase II?
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy
This is true to enroll via cs.  Of course, the chem and physics sections will have their own policies to follow.
Do Chemistry majors in the College of Chemistry have reserved seats?
Physics 7C is really the course that covers quantum (and optics) and topics which are not absolute prerequisites for all engineers e.g. civil to materials science

What's the relevant material from Physics 7A and 7B? 
I am LSCS so I didn't take those particular courses, but I've taken other physics courses and I'm wondering what material I should look up if I'm interested in taking this class.
3 units.
How many units is this class?
Fa 14 homeworks looks like problem sets. (I'd also be impressed if they thought up some programming assignment involving quantum systems)
Thanks!

What is the workload of this class like? Is the homework mostly in the form of programming or solving problem sets? 

 I am taking physics 137A this semester and the homework is basically solving problems. I wonder if it is similar for this class? Thanks!!!
The in-person version is better.
In what ways? There is obviously the opportunity to talk with instructors about the material, but are there content differences? Updates to the approach? More extensive material?
I'm curious as well. Seeing as there's no discussion section, just seeing an in-person lecture isn't a huge draw
I'm curious as well, especially given that the instructor (Vazirani) is the least approachable professor I have ever seen in the 4 yrs I've been here.
How will the in-person version compare to the archived online version on edX?
Thanks for the heads-up!
Thanks!

CCNs for CS and Chem in case physics fills up.

COMPSCI: 34017

CHEM: 34073

PHYSICS: 34072

The class is up! It's listed under Physics on schedule.berkeley.edu.
CCN: 34072
yes, I have hope
If it's being taught in HP then unlikely. That room wasn't equipped for webcasts last year so it's probably not possible even if professor vazirani wants to.
any hope of it being webcasted?
[Wait, you said waitlist, not lecture. Waitlist looks like it should be open, according to schedule.berkeley.edu]
hmm that's weird. When I try to add the class it says that the waitlist is full.
It says waitlist is full when I try to add the class. Did it really fill up that quickly?
You can look that up at http://guide.berkeley.edu
No prereqs listed there... although someone above in this thread quoted the 7 series and more.

That means there are no official prerequisites to the course.  It is likely that means that the various department faculty knew that students would come to the course with various levels of preparation received via various pathways.
What are the official pre-reqs?
Yes. I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.
Can i sign up for the physics or chem sections but still get credit for a cs upper div?
Unlikely, but you can ask Prof Vazirani.
Will there be alternate final exams offered? I have to take Math 110 next semester, which has the same lecture time as this class.
Because that's what the faculty who created this course wanted.

Cross-listed courses allow each department to set its own enrollment policy (e.g. prioritizing its own majors), allow students of both/all departments involved to be able to choose whether to treat the class as a class in their department for their major or outside as a breadth, et cetera.

In the old enrollment system, at least, enrollment for the different departments' versions of a cross-listed class was completely separate. Can't tell if this is still the same.

Thanks Steven.  In this case, the new system is actually more flexible.  What I mean, is that in a cross-listed course, the departments can set a global enrollment limit X and the sum of the enrollment limits for the multiple sections don't have to = X.  The sum can be > X so that while no more than X students can sign up for the class as a whole, it may be that for some or all of X there is no system preference for which department is used as the vehicle for an individual student to sign up.

C191 is set up that way with current enrollment max of 64 students being accessible from any of the three listings.

Why does each department have its own enrollment list? Are all waitlists unified in ordering (e.g. someone in the CS category can be enrolled after someone from Chem drops) or does someone in the CS category have to drop before someone else is added to the CS category?
They were posted earlier in this thread.
I still can't find the class CN or in the scheduler! Am I doing something wrong?
Similarly, as an Engineering Physics major, should i pick the physics dept? I would need this to count for an upper div cs requirement for an EECS minor, so I'm currently on the CS waitlist.
I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.
If I'm a CS major, should I sign up for the wait list under the CS department? CS has a much longer wait list than Physics or Chem.
No. I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.
Do you know if this is true for all three departments?
I only know this is true for cs/eecs/

Does it matter which of the three departments I sign up for? I want to use this class towards a physics minor, but I'm enrolled in the Chem department's C191. I figure it shouldn't matter since it's the same class.
same
No. It is not likely to get expanded.

Is the class likely to get expanded? Based on the response to the Facebook post on the CS group, I think a lot of students are going to be disappointed if they are not able to take the course next semester.
asking the right questions
I think so but that is completely up to the instructor so you should feel free to approach Prof Vazirani.
Will the Chemistry / Physics versions of the class be graded on the same curve? I am not sure if I should stay on the Chem waitlist.
"Closed" means something in calcentral but not necessarily what we would expect it to.
Why is the class closed? CalCentral says the wait list capacity is 120 and there are only 78 on the wait list

To have a discussion about the chemistry department's management of their enrollment lists, you'll have to reach out to staff in Chemistry.

In terms of are there seats set aside for specific department's entry: no. There are 64 seats total and any department can enroll anywhere from 0 t 64 students as long as the final total is =/< 64.
Is there a way to find out who's managing the chem waitlist?
I'd contact the advisors in Chemistry; they either are or know who are the relevant parties that manage the chem waitlist.

Are seats being saved in each section for the respective majors? The Chemistry section only had 5 people enrolled when I was 1st on the waitlist, and now it has 6 people enrolled but I'm still 1st on the waitlist.

Secondarily, how many seats are being allocated for each section?

history.content:
C/PHY/CS 191: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Computation

Instructor: Prof. Umesh Vazirani
TuTh 11-12:30 306 Soda Hall (HP Auditorium)

Spring 2017 

 

Quantum computation is a remarkable subject building on the great computational discovery that computers based on quantum mechanics are exponentially powerful. This course aims to make this cutting-edge material broadly accessible to undergraduate students, including computer science majors who do not have any prior exposure to quantum mechanics. The course starts with a simple introduction to the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics using the concepts of qubits (or quantum bits) and quantum gates. This treatment emphasizes the paradoxical nature of the subject, including entanglement, non-local correlations, the no-cloning theorem and quantum teleportation. The course covers the fundamentals of quantum algorithms, including the quantum fourier transform, period finding, Shor's quantum algorithm for factoring integers, as well as the prospects for quantum algorithms for NP-complete problems. We will also discuss the basic ideas behind the physical implementation of qubits and quantum gates, as well as progress in the experimental realization of quantum computers.

THE FACULTY OF THIS COURSE ARE NOT READING THIS THREAD. YOU SHOULD DIRECT YOUR QUESTIONS TO THEM VIA EMAIL.
history.subject: CS 191: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Computation

history.content:
This course is not in schedule.berkeley.edu yet, but it should

be shortly.
